NOTES: A Berber student died in police custody at a police station in Beni Douala.
Five people were killed in 3 days of rioting across the Kabyle region after a student died in police custody in Beni Douala. Protesters threw stones and set fire to public buildings.

Berber protesters and police fought running battles in Tizi Ouzou and Bejaia. At least 13 were killed on Apr.28. At least 42 people reported killed and over 400 injured in total, mostly police, since Apr.23 according to official figures.

About 5,000 people staged a peaceful anti-government protest in Algiers. They engaged in a sit-in outside the PM's office while riot police and helicopters were deployed but did not interact with the protesters.

Separately from a sit-in staged the same day, between 10-20,000 people marched in Algiers under the banner of the Front for Socialist Forces against recent violence in the Kabyle region. There were no reports of violence.
About 200 lawyers marched to the Bejaia city hall to show support for those killed recently in Kabyle.

Sporadic protests and clashes were reported, centring mainly in the Bejaia region, including youths barricading roads with trees and tires set on fire. Dozens of people were said to have been injured, although officially there were no injuries. The protests took place in El Keur, Oued Ghir, Bakaro, Tichy, Soul El Thenine, Bordj Mira, Kerrata, and Aokas.

A high school student was shot and killed during clashes between protesters and police in the Bouzegene area.
A police officer was killed during clashes between protesters and police in the Tizi Ouzou area.
Protests and clashes continued across the Kabyle region against poverty, unemployment and government policies in the region.
One person was killed and 7 injured in clashes beween protesters and police in Cheurfa in the Tizi Ouzou area.
Riots were reported in nearly every neighbourhood of Tizi Ouzou. It was not clear if police became involved.
Riots were reported in towns near Cheurfa, where a youth was killed in clashes between protesters and police.
Rioting was reported in Bejaia, where the city's local radio station was set on fire. It was not clear if police became involved.
Youths took to the streets in Azazga, Karbaa Nath Irathen and Tizi Ouzou, leading to sporadic scuffles reported between protesters and police.

SOURCE: Associated Press Online; Associated Press International
NOTES: Youths took to the streets in Azazga, Karbaa Nath Irathen and Tizi Ouzou, leading to sporadic scuffles reported between protesters and police.
The Liberte Daily reported that 2 more deaths due to rioting had occurred on Monday. Both were allegedly shot by police, although the locations of the shootings were not reported.
Clashes between police and protesters erupted in Ain El Hammam, Iferhounene, and Beni Douala.
Students protested in the Algerian capital to show solidarity with Berber protesters in Kabyle.
Clashes between police and protesters erupted in Ain El Hammam, Iferhounene, and Beni Douala.

Youths clashed with security forces in Tizi Ouzou during protests against the government despit the replacement of police in the area after a number of deaths during protests in April. Numerous roads were barricaded by protesters while police used tear gas to attempt to disperse them.
636 gendarmes, including commanding officers, were transferred out of the Kabyle region following deaths of over 50 people during protests since April. The move was meant to quell anger in the area.
The Liberte Daily reported that 3 civilians were killed by suspected GIA militants at a road block near Ain Delfa.
The El Watan newspaper reported that 6 militants were killed by security forces in the Setif region.

Thousands of doctors, nurses and medical workers marched in Tizi Ouzou over the security forces handling of unrest in the region, specifically violence against demonstrators and rioters. Some clashes between police and protesters were reported at the end of the march.

Police used clubs and water cannons to disperse thousands of people in Algiers who demonstrated despite the protest being banned by Algerian authorities. Protesters threw stones at police and denounced the handling of recent unrest in the Kabyle region.
A local newspaper reported that 6 members of a local self-defense group were killed by militants as they patrolled in the Bordj Emir Khaled area.

Recent unrest in the Kabyle region has spread to the Aures area, with several days of demonstrations reported in Sour el Ghozlane, Sidi Amar, Ain Kercha and Khencella. Clashes between demonstrators and police were reported and with some arrests made.

24 people were reported injured in rioting in the Ain Fakroun area of the Aures region.
Police entered Algiers main hospital to arrest demonstrators who had taken refuge there, and mandhandled at least one doctor, although no injuries were reported.
Anti-government protesters clashed with police in Tizi Ouzou.

Youths attacked some people who had been wounded in the recent large Berber demo in the capital who were leaving Algiers main hospital. It's not clear why they were attacked. The youths were armed with knives and other edged weapons.
Clashes between police and protesters were reported in Tizi Ouzou after the burial of a young man who died during the demo in Algiers.
Anti-government protesters attacked public buildings, burned cars and clashed with police in the Tizi Ouzou. Dozens were reported injured, although official figures were not released.
4 members of a self-defense group were killed by suspected GIA militants as they were refilling a water tank.
20 soldiers were killed and several others wounded in an ambush on their convoy by suspected GIA militants in the Chlef area.
A police officer was killed and 3 others wounded in an ambush by Islamic rebels in the Jijel area. The ambush began with a remote bomb blast followed by small arms fire.
Anti-government protesters clashed with police in Tizi Ouzou.
Local newspapers reported that 3 police officers were killed during rioting in the Kabyle region.
Rioting was reported in Ain Lassel in the Batna region, Ain Legradj, Teleghma, and Beni Amrane. Clashes with police were suspected, although no injuries were reported.
A protester died during rioting and suspected clashes with police in the Ain Mlila area near Oum El-Bouagh.

ACTOR1: GSPC: Salafist Group for Call and Combat
NOTES: 2 police were shot dead near the towns of Ouzellaguen and Akbou by suspected GSPC militants (fatalities split across 2 events).
One protester was killed during rioting and clashes with police in Akbou. Over 100 people were injured in the rioting.
A paramilitary gendarme was killed in Azazga by unidentified assailants.
Rioting was reported in Ain Lassel in the Batna region, Ain Legradj, Teleghma, and Beni Amrane. Clashes with police were suspected, although no injuries were reported.
Rioting was reported in Ain Lassel in the Batna region, Ain Legradj, Teleghma, and Beni Amrane. Clashes with police were suspected, although no injuries were reported.
2 police were killed during rioting in Bordj Mira.
30 people were injured in rioting and suspected clashes between police and protesters in Bouira. 50 people were reported injured in similar events across the region outside Bouira itself.
30 people were injured in rioting and suspected clashes between police and protesters in Bouira. 50 more people were reported injured in similar events across the region outside Bouira itself.
A protester died during rioting and suspected clashes with police in Ain Touta in the Aures region.
One protester was killed during rioting and clashes with police in Larbaa Nath Irathen.

ACTOR1: GSPC: Salafist Group for Call and Combat
NOTES: 2 police were shot dead near the towns of Ouzellaguen and Akbou by suspected GSPC militants (fatalities split across 2 events).
Rioting was reported in Ain Lassel in the Batna region, Ain Legradj, Teleghma, and Beni Amrane. Clashes with police were suspected, although no injuries were reported.
A police officer was killed in Tizi Ouzou by unidentified assailants.

Organizers said as many as 65,000 people marched in Tizi Ouzou to commemorate the 3rd anniversary of the death of a popular Berber singer who was killed by Muslim militants in 1998. The march ended peacefully while police lined the roads to prevent violence but did not interact with the marchers.
After a large march ended peacefully, skirmishes broke out between police and youths in Tizi Ouzou. The youths threw stones while the police retaliated with tear gas to disperse them.
A general strike was called in the Kabyle region ahead of a planned march.
Hundreds of Berber protesters staged a sit-in in Algiers over the government's ban on street demonstrations which prevented a planned march in the city. They later dispersed peacefully.
Sporadic rioting broke out in Tizi Ouzou where hundreds of protesting youths clashed with police. At least 6 protesters were injured.
Protesters and police clashed during rioting in Tizi Ouzou.
About 50 armed assailants entered a hospital in Azazga, locked security guards in a room, and then stole surgical equipment, medicine and cash. No injuries were reported.
10 people were killed in an attack by unidentified assailants in the Mousziz region, south of Algiers.

Police used armored cars to block Berber protesters from entering Algiers, leading to scuffles as some protesters attempted to force their way past the roadblocks. Several protesters received minor injuries and dozens more were arrested.
5 members of a family were killed and 3 others wounded in an attack by suspected GIA militants in Ouled Djellal.
Youths protested and clashed with police who fired tear gas and used water cannons in Tizi Ouzou during a visit by the Interior Minister.

5 militants were captured by several dozen villagers who then turned them over to the authorities after they attempted to break into a local mosque's strongbox in the Ait Oumalou area of Kabyle, east of Tizi Ouzou.
5 suspected militants were killed during an army raid in the village of Kherbet Siouf Drag in the Medea region. 2 soldiers were injured during the attack.
Nearly 100,000 people marched peacefully through the Soummam Valley to protest against the government and its treatment of Berbers.
43 people have been reported killed in massacres in the Mascara region over the last two weeks (reported on Sept.1, 28 fatalities reported in other events).
2 soldiers and 2 members of a civilian defense group were killed in an ambush by suspected GIA militants after their patrols ran into land mines at Ait Chefaa.

The government has agreed to officially recognize the native language of the Berbers a major, compensate victims of police brutality, and prosecute those responsible, all major demands which has been behind Berber protests since April 2001.

Police prevented Berbers from staging a protest march in Algiers, blocking roads and arresting at least several dozen people as they attempted to assemble. Others who made it past the police staged a sit-in before dispersing peacefully.
During riots in the Kabyle region, 3 protesters were hit by rubber bullets fired by gendarmes in Beni Douala, injuring 2 seriously.
Protesting Berber youths clashed with police in several towns around the Kabyle region. 10 people were injured in the confrontations.
2 police officers were killed by suspected GIA militants in Draa el-Mizan.
2 youths were killed after they found a home-made bomb in the Ait Ouabane area that went off after they tried to inspect it.
A local GLD chief was killed by suspected GIA militants in the Boudjelal el-Ghorf area. Another GLD member was injured in the attack.
3 security personnel and 2 suspected GIA militants were killed in an operation over the weekend to clear the Oran area.

3 suspected GIA militants were killed in two encounters with security forces (fatalities split across 2 events). One was near Tizi Ouzou and another was in Boumerdas. Specific fatalities for each fight were not reported.
7 members of the security forces were killed by suspected GIA militants in Collo.

3 suspected GIA militants were killed in two encounters with security forces (fatalities split across 2 events). One was near Tizi Ouzou and another was in Boumerdas. Specific fatalities for each fight were not reported.
4 civilians were killed when their vehicle hit a mine in the Djelfa area.
4 members of the security forces were killed in a gunfight with suspected GIA militants in the Oran area.

SOURCE: Jeune Afrique; Tout sur l'Algerie; Xinhua
NOTES: Algeria has witnessed a series of riots across the country after the Budget Law 2017, which includes tax hikes and austerity measures, entered into force. A call for a three-day strike starting from Sunday was largely followed in some regions, including Bejaia, 280 km in the east of the capital Algiers. Some angry youngsters on Monday took to the streets, looted some stores, burned out public properties and clashed with anti-riot forces in Bejaia. Clashes between youngsters and security forces, however, were reported on Wednesday, as several protesters were arrested pending trial. Other towns involved in the riots were Sidi Aich, Taskriout, Tichy, Akbou, El Akseur, Souk El Tenine, Saharidji.
Local merchants also striked in Bouira against the tax increases planned in the national budget.
Local merchants also striked in Bouira against the tax increases planned in the national budget.
Communal employees entered on strike on Monday.
Two armed militants were killed in a military operation in Laghouat.

An eight-year-old child was killed on Monday when an abandoned homemade bomb exploded in the locality of Mouzaia, in the province of Blida. The explosion injured seven other children aged between seven and 10, who were rushed to Frantz Fanon Hospital to get medical treatment. The bomb was likely abandoned by terrorist groups, given that the mountains and woods of the province of Blida used to be stronghold for terrorists in the 1990.
Local merchants also striked in Bouira against the tax increases planned in the national budget.
500 workers in the education sector in the province of Relizane demanding the payment of their pensions.

Kamal Eddine Fekhar, former executive member of LADDH, started a hunger strike. He was arrested after the violence in Ghardaia in the summer of 2015.
A sit was staged in Sidi Bel Abbes to protest against the demolition of some neighbourhoods.
Riots were reported in Bab el Oued area of Algiers.
For the second consecutive days, demonstrators in Bouira province blocked the highway in El Adjiba. Gendarmerie intervened to disperse the sit-in.
Clashes between rioters and gendarmes continued on Wednesday in Saharidj.
Dental health students in the University of Oran started a protest movement with a strike in the beginning of January.
A group of public employees protested on Thursday in Tebessa.
Twenty eight bombs, one homemade canon and two caches for militants were destroyed Friday, in Ain Defla and Bouira.
Citizens protested in Mahelma against the deterioration of living conditions.
The citizens of a mountainous village protested in Mesdour and demanded their area to be served with natural gas.
Two armed militants were killed in the area of Ain Kechra by the army.
Students striked in Constantine.

NOTES: MAK organised a march on the first day of the Amazigh year. The demonstrators chanted pro-independence slogans and demanded independence from Algeria.
Public employees have been on strike for one week.
Students from the Ecole superieure des beaux arts in Algiers launched a strike in mid-January.
After a dead man was found in a river nearby, residents of Boutamina area blocked the road connecting Skikda to Jijel near Oum Toub and demanded more security.
One militant has been killed on Friday afternoon by a detachment of the People's National Army in the zone of El Hadria, in El Milia region in Jijel province
Chinese workers staged a protest sit-in in Souk Ahras.

Algerian anti-terrorism troops on Friday discovered a load of war weapons in the province of Tamanrasset, near the Malian border. Army troops deployed near the border with Mali discovered a terror bunker containing 22 war weapons and ammunition, said the ministry. Rocket launchers, machine guns of different calibers, and ammunition were retrieved.
Theatre workers protested in Bejaia

NOTES: Trade unions organised demonstrations in Blida, Batna, Oran and Ouargla.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: UNPEF: National Union of Education and Training Employees; SNAPEST: National Union of Secondary and Technical Education Teachers
NOTES: Trade unions organised demonstrations in Blida, Batna, Oran and Ouargla.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
NOTES: Active protests have been ongoing for at least twelve days in Ouargla. A group of unemployed, under the banne of the CNDDC, are staging a sit-in to demand that the director of the local agency for employment is fired.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
NOTES: Active protests have been ongoing for at least twelve days in Ouargla. A group of unemployed, under the banne of the CNDDC, are staging a sit-in to demand that the director of the local agency for employment is fired.
Students marched in protest in Skikda after another pupil was killed.
Residents protesting the absence of appropriate gas infrastructure in the area staged a demonstration outside the town hall of Constantine.
Five prisoners have started a hunger strike in El Menia. They were arrested after the violence in Ghardaia of 2015.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
NOTES: Active protests have been ongoing for at least twelve days in Ouargla. A group of unemployed, under the banne of the CNDDC, are staging a sit-in to demand that the director of the local agency for employment is fired.
A march and a protest sit-in outside the offices of the local regional administration were organised by medecine students of the University of Oran. They demand a meeting with government authorities.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
NOTES: Active protests have been ongoing for at least twelve days in Ouargla. A group of unemployed, under the banne of the CNDDC, are staging a sit-in to demand that the director of the local agency for employment is fired.

Three gunmen, described as 'terrorists-drug traffickers' by the army, were killed Wednesday in an ambush set in in El Hamra zone, Illizi region, by a detachment of the People's National Army (ANP), which also seized weapons, ammunition and a large quantity of cannabis.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
NOTES: Active protests have been ongoing for at least twelve days in Ouargla. A group of unemployed, under the banne of the CNDDC, are staging a sit-in to demand that the director of the local agency for employment is fired.
Parents of pupils protested in Oued el Berdi and blocked roads to denounce the absence of school buses.
Demonstrators protested in Souk El Tenine blocking the national road linking Setif to Bejaia. They took to the streets after the release of the names of public housing beneficiaries.
The absence of gas infrastructure in Haizer area prompted protests by local residents, who blocked the RN33 leading to Tikdja park.
Traders launched a three-day strike in Constantine.
Students from the Ecole superieure des beaux arts in Algiers escalated their strike and started a hunger strike on Monday 6 February.
Students staged a sit-in in Bouzegune to protest the absence of adequate school transport.
Residents in El Medjaz, near El Euch, blocked the road to protest the absence of school transport.
Fruits sellers staged a sit-in in the centre of Msotaganem.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers
NOTES: Public employees entered on strike on Wednesday in Ali Mendjeli.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: UGCAA: General Union of Algerian Merchants and Artisans
NOTES: Bakers strike in Annaba
The municipality of Arzew saw new protests as public housing applciants took to the streets.
Several strikes are disrupting lectures in the University of Bouira.
Retail sellers staged a strike in Ghazaouene on Thursday.

Algeria's army troops found on Friday a large quantity of war weapons in a bunker near the border with Mali, in Adrar province. Weapons retrieved included a SPG-9 gun, two 14.5mm machine guns, a 12.7mm machine gun, a PKT machine gun, three RPK machine guns, two Kalashnikov machine guns, a SKS semi-automatic rifle, a repeating rifle, a MAS-36 rifle, seven D-30 shells, 15 mortar shells, 18 SPG-9 rockets, three RPG-7 rockets, two Grad BM missiles, 10 F1 grenades and a large quantity of ammunition

Teachers took to the streets to protest evidence of fraud in the hiring process of new teachers. On the same day, veterans from Angola's guerrilla war protested that their pensions have not been paid for 2 months.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: MJSPL: Movement of the People's Protectorate of Lunda Tchokwe
NOTES: More than 2000 people protested in the streets of Cafunfo, demanding the autonomy of the Tchokwe people.
FNLA members held a demonstration in Malanje on the Day of Martyrs, but the police broke it up, claiming that FNLA had not obtained permission to demonstrate.
Teachers took to the streets to protest evidence of fraud in the hiring process of new teachers. 4 teachers were arrested when the police broke up the protest.
Activists advocating that Lunda Sul be made a protectorate protested outside the police station following the release of activists and leaders who had been arrested for planning a demonstration.

Clashes between members of a congregation from Gbaname church and Vodou-cult followers on the Bohicon-Abomey axis in Djime after provocations left two people dead, several others injured and caused significant material damage.
Around a hundred specialised doctors held a sit-in at the national hospital and teaching centre of Cotonou to launch an unlimited strike calling for improved working conditions.

Hundreds of national and international media professionals held a sit-in in Cotonou, calling for the re-opening of four TV channels and a radio station shut down by authorities. Police intervened to disperse the protest.
Primary and secondary school teachers launched a two day strike calling for better working conditions.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: FESEN: Federation of Unions of National Education of Benin
NOTES: FESEN launched a 72h strike calling for better working conditions. The strike was partially followed by teachers.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CSTB: Confederation of Trade Unions of Benin
NOTES: Couffo syndicates affiliated to the CSTB staged a peaceful march in Aplahoue to protest bad governance, particularly in response to the various strike movements held by teachers and doctors in the country.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SYNAPAR: National Union of Research Support Staff
NOTES: SYNAPAR members staged a sit-in at the Institute of Environment and Agricultural Research in Ouagadougou to demand a sepcific allowance and expansion of a premium for their research.
Students in the Niangoloko locality under the banner of the Association of Schools Comoe (CSA) began a 72-hour strike to draw attention to their grievances.
Rallies were held against the continued use of the CFA in Burkina Faso.
One person was killed and another injured when Burkinabe soldiers fired warnings shots at approaching motorcycles in the Banh area of Loroum province.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
NOTES: The Union of Lawyers of Burkina Faso (SYNAF) reported that a lawyer had been assaulted by police while he had been attempting to interview a defendant who had been in custody for more than 5 days.
1,500 people marched silently in Ouagadougou to mark the anniversary of the Hotel Splendid attack.
Students in Santa blocked National Road No.7 to demand attention to their grievances.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.

Retired police and soldiers protested and staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Defence and Veteran's Affairs in Ouagadougou over the government's non-implementation of a shift in the retirement age.

Heavily armed Islamist militants were reported to have forced their way into schools in areas around Baraboule, including the Petega area of Pelem-Pelem and Lassa, and demanded teachers instruct their students on Islam and the Quran and stop teaching French. Burkinabe soldiers have been deployed to the area following the incidents.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
NOTES: A crowd forced the release of 8 people imprisoned at a police station in Bagre. Following the events, clashes were reported between the rioters and police, which were later reinforced by gendarmerie forces. 37 people were arrested after the incident. No casualties were reported but some property was damaged.
A municipal councilor and his son were killed by unidentified assailants in the Yorsala area, near Titao.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SYNAFI: National Union of Finance Agents
NOTES: SYNAFI workers began an 11 day sit-in outside the ministry to demand their grievances be addressed.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: ONTTB: National Organisation of Burkinabe Land Carriers
NOTES: Truck drivers of the ONTTB protested and blocked the Ouaga-Kaya intersection to demand fewer road checks. They threatened to strike if nothing was done.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SYTTBHA: Workers Union of Public Works, Building, Water and Similar
NOTES: SYTTBHA workers protested and staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Infrastructure to demand resolution of their grievances.
A woman was killed when a grenade was thrown at her family while they were resting.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A bicycle taxi driver was arrested, tied up, and beaten by Imbonerakure because he was not carrying his ID. They accused him of belonging to a rebel group.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A small-trader who was collecting a debt from another person was delivered to the Imbonerakure, who beat him. He was then imprisoned for 2 days.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: At least 20 people were arrested and accused of having taken part in an attack on Kayogoro.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
ALLY_ACTOR_2: MSD: Movement for Solidarity and Development
NOTES: A member of MSD was assaulted by a member of the CNDD-FDD. His assailant threatened to kill him if he did not adhere to CNDD-FDD

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A man was tortured and imprisoned by Imbonerakure. He was accused of criticising the administration.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
NOTES: A woman was attacked by a CNDD-FDD, then later in the evening her house was burned down.
The governor of Makamba discovered 11 people watching a video together during a curfew patrol. He had them severely beaten.
A woman was abducted and tortured. Her arm was cut off and she was killed. Her body was found two days later near her home.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure assaulted a man and threw his unconscious body in a cornfield because he is not a member of CNDD-FDD

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A woman was assaulted by Imbonerakure at around 7pm.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A 17 year old boy was beaten by 3 Imbonerakure.
A man who had fought a policeman in a bar was arrested and detained. In the police cells he was assaulted by 2 policemen
3 youths were arrested and put in a common cell. One was tortured with sticks.
A Batwa man was beaten to death.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure assaulted a man who had argued with his wife. She pleaded that they not arrest him because their quarrel was domestic.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A restaurant waiter was beaten by Imbonerakure until he lost consciousness
A man who had been accused of being a rainmaker was killed because of the lack of rains.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A man was arrested and beaten up because the police accused him of stealing the deputy head of the commune's kepi. The police and imbonerakure threatened to shoot him in the head and made him pay BIF300,000 to avoid going to prison.
A young girl was attacked by unidentified assailants and seriously wounded.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Burundi (2005-) National Intelligence Service
ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: The FNL Rwasa vice president was arrested and accused of illegal distribution and possession of weapons. 6 other FNL Rwasa members are being held on the same charges.
A shopkeeper was abducted.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: Police in Gihanga arrested 5 men, including 3 FNL Rwasa activists after a household search. The men were accused of attacking the internal security of the state.
8 people were injured when a grenade exploded in the Church of Heaven. The pastor has been arrested.
The Burundi Minister of the Environment, Emmanuel Niyokuru, was killed by gunmen on his way home.

A transmission agent for the local police commissioner assaulted 2 men with his belt and fined them BIF100,000. He accused them of having been at a clandestine meeting because they were returning from a bar. The next day the police returned the money to the men so that would not file a case.
A woman disappeared from a Gikungu bar. 4 days later her body was found on the shores of Lake Tanganyika.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure staged a march to protest against Rwanda.
A policeman shot at 2 young boys who were herding cattle, killing one and injuring the other.
A staff member of the NGO CARE was abducted by policemen and driven to Bugarama in a civilian car.
A student detonated a grenade at school, which killed him.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: A man on Masha hill was beaten until he lost consciousness by 2 Imbonerakure. One of them has been arrested.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: 2 Imbonerakure beat a man until he lost consciousness because he refused to buy them a drink.
Construction workers discovered a mass grave in Rusaka. 6 skulls have been found.
2 people suspected of witchcraft were killed by their neighbours, who wielded clubs and machetes.
3 families were attacked by unkown assailants wielding cudgels. The families were told that they were attacked because they were known to support General Niyombare.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: An imbonerakure assaulted the head of the hill who had demanded a fine.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
NOTES: A CNDD-FDD party activist was attacked by unknown assailants.
A woman was killed by villagers, who believed that she was a witch.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure accused a man of stealing a goat and beat him to death. They were arrested but released soon after.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: 2 men were decapitated and dismembered by Imbonerakure.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure assaulted a man and a woman and locked them up. The imbonerakure accused them of adultery, but it is believed that they were targeted because the woman is from Musaga, a hot spot during the anti-Nkurunziza protests.
Unidentified armed men killed 2 men and a child in a shooting in Muyira. 6 people have been arrested.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
NOTES: A CNDD-FDD militant was killed by unidentified assailants. His body was found on 14 January
A man was arrested and beaten by order of the head of the police post, who heard him insulting the police while drunk.
A man was arrested by the police. His body was discovered the next day by the cowherds. The local authorities issued an urgent order to bury the boy without an investigation.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: 2 Imbonerakure attacked an FNL Agathon Rwasa member with machetes. They accused him of having left the CNDD-FDD.
The police carried out a household search. They assaulted a man who resisted them when they attempted to enter his house.

ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: Unidentified armed men attacked the household of a member of FNL Rwasa. He was injured. One of the attackers was also injured, when neighbours came to his rescue.
A man accused of witchcraft was killed. 10 people have been arrested.
2 brothers were attacked by people throwing grenades at around 11pm. 1 died on the spot and the other was wounded.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure attacked a couple who support UPRONA with machetes.
When soldiers discovered a grenade on a plot, they beat the girl who lived there with their rifle butts until the Deputy Head of the hill intervened.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: An FNL Rwasa supporter was attacked in a bar for resisting joining the ruling party.
A man was attacked by unidentified men armed with guns and machetes.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure clubbed a man to death when he was caught in an act of robbery in a field of beans.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: The administrator of the commune was attacked by Imbonerakure in his home.
Police assaulted a young man near the Musaga market. When onlookers attempted to help him, they chased them away.
A shepherd was killed.
A man and his sister were talking outside her home, when they were apprehended by police and beaten. The man lost consciousness.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: 9 youth who did not have identity documents were assaulted by Imbonerakure and then taken to the communal police station.

Unidentified gunmen attacked Mukoni Military camp in the early hours of Tuesday morning. Following this incident a patrol went out and burned the savannah where the gunmen were reportedly hiding to flush them out.

ACTOR1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: An imbonerakure raped a 14 year old school girl as she returned home.

Following the an attack on the Mukoni camp, Warrant Officer Francis Nkunzimana and around 30 other soldiers were arrested and handed over to the police. The next day Nkunzimana's body was found on the savannah, riddled with bullets, along with two other bodies. One of the other soldiers arrested was beheaded. The other soldiers complained of severe torture.
A woman's body was found in her home, hacked by machetes.
Major Dieudonne Karashira was killed at Cankuzo Military camp. A man has been arrested in response.

ACTOR1: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
ALLY_ACTOR_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
NOTES: The CNDD-FDD leader of the Baziro area beat an FNL Rwasa supporter at around 7pm for opposing the payment of contributions to the party building project.
The government of Burundi released 2,500 prisoners (nearly a quarter of the prison population)
Between 7pm and 8pm police overturned stalls and forced traders to close their shops. The traders grew angry and threw stones at the police. The police fired into the air to disperse the crowd.
A body was found on 28/1. The victim was wearing handcuffs and had been shot in the head.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
NOTES: Members of the CNDD-FDD held a march to protest against the EU, Human Rights Watch, and Iteka, who have criticised the Burundian government.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
NOTES: Imbonerakure marched to demonstrate against the EU report which criticised the Burundian government.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: CNDD: National Council for Democracy and Development
NOTES: Members of the CNDD-FDD held a march to protest against the EU, Human Rights Watch, and Iteka, who have criticised the Burundian government.

NOTES: Members of the CNDD-FDD held a march to protest against the EU, Human Rights Watch, and Iteka, who have criticised the Burundian government.
