JISA forces conducted a security operation where they intercepted two IEDs in two different villages in Shaqallaha and Farjano neighbourhoods. One of the IEDs was confirmed to have been planted on the road to the Caymiska Pavilion near Kumadaha teashops in Farjano neighbourhood. The targets were not clear. JISA EOD team safely dismantled the devices. The Hormuud antenna was shut down during the process. There were no reports of arrests made.

There was a celebration in Mogadishu city after the declaration of the newly elected President of Somalia. A large group of people gathered in Tarabunka square despite the lockdown of the city for the last two days. Somali security forces joined into the excitement where they fired live rounds into the air in different locations in the city which caused panic among residents. One woman was shot and killed while at least five other persons were injured by stray bullets.

Pro-ISIL fighters and Puntland security forces clashed at Qandala. Reports on causalities could not be established at the time of reporting. Local reports indicated that pro-ISIL fighters cut off all water sources in the town.
A suspected thief was subjected to the as the victim of a mob attack  in Kanana informal settlement in Gugulethu. He was killed in the attack.
Residents of Schornville outside King William's Town marched to the town's magistrate's court to oppose bail in a rape case.
Community member allegedly assautled a man in Seweding near Mahikeng. The man died of his injuries.
A mob killed a suspected criminal in Wesernburg outside Polokwane.
Paramedics protested outside the Khayelitsha Magistrates's court over the string of attacks they have been the target of.
A riotous mob went on the rampage attacking and looting tuckshops owned by foreigners in Kuruman.
More than 100 parents from Mamelodi in Pretoria East burned tyres on Tsamaya road to display their frustrations over the new online registration system.
Residents protested and blocked the R536 in Bushbuckridge with boulders and branches, saying promises of jobs have gone unfulfilled.
Mine workers staged a sit-in protest inside a mine at the Kusasalethu mine in the West Rand.
ANC supporters protested outside the Roodepoort Magistrate's Court urging the court not to grant a suspected murderer bail.

Anti-Riotpolice fought sporadicbattleswith protesters who threw rocks at passing cars and burned barricades on the busy R72 coastal road between Nelson Mandela Bay and Buffalo City metros at Kenton-on-Sea.

Schooling has been disrupted by protesting residents, unhappy with the state of roads in the Tshitale area in Makhado, Limpopo. Three government vehicles and a building were torched during the protest.

Shots were fired, people injured and insults hurled as Mnquma municipality's power struggle turned violent as ANC factions clashing over a council decision to end with immediate effect Sindile Tantsi's municipal manager contract. A brawl broke out and the groups pelted one another with stones until shots were fired from the municipal buildings.
A group of about 200 people camped outside the municipal offices in Butterworth demanding the removal of municipal manager Sandile Tantsi.
Protesting residents continued to protest over the completion of road in the Tshitale area. There was no reports of violence on the second day of the protest.
At least 60 people wearing T-shirts with images of a baby, who was killed, protested against bail for two murder accused at Simon's Town Magistrate's court.
A man was burnt to death by a mob after he was accused of raping two girls in Moeka, north of Pretoria.
ANC members assaulted the DA Candidate for ward 25, Marchell Kleynhans in Uniondale, Western Cape.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Students (South Africa); NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union; SASSU: South African Social Services Union
NOTES: Central Johannesburg TVET College students and members of trade union Nehawu protested in Alexandra. Students had barricaded London Road and 13th Avenue with burning tyres and garbage.
Residents in Ga-Rankuwa took to the streets in protest. Several roads were barricaded with burning tyres and large boulders. School children in the area could not attend classes.

Over a two day period, parents, who support the newly appointed principal atg a school in Kimberly, Northern Cape, gathered in front the school in protest over a court interdict has halted the appointment of a school principal.
A school and post office were set alight during violent protest action in Tshitale, Limpopo over education.
Blind employees of Are-Itireleng Trust in Ga-Rankuwa took to the streets, accusing their managers of denying them access to money, company cars and office space.

Over a two day period, parents, who support the newly appointed principal atg a school in Kimberly, Northern Cape, gathered in front the school in protest over a court interdict has halted the appointment of a school principal.
Police arrested 19 people in Mphephu for public violence, after protesters barricaded the R523 road.
Protesters gathered outside the Bafokeng Magistrate's Court during the appearance of community activist Napoleon Webster.
Another school was set alight in ongoing violent protest action in Tshitale, Limpopo.
Frustrated community members of Freedom Park stormed the premises of town planners in protest in Milpark, decrying the lack of community beneficiation for the mainly informal settlement.
There was a small contingent of supporters for Fees Must Fall student Bonginkosi Khanyile ahead of his pre-trial conference at Durban Magistrate's Court.
Students protested, burnt tyres and carried placards outside the Thuto Bophelo Nursing Academy in Pretoria.
Family members of a murderedwomen staged a picket outside the Durban Magistrates Court.
Lectures were brought to a halt at Buffalo City Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College in East London when students joined a nationwide shutdown at colleges yesterday
Commissioner Road in Boksburg has been re-opened following a protest. Rubble, stones and burning tyres were used during the demonstration by a group of people claiming to be living nearby.
Women gathered at Cape Towns Companys Gardens for a "Sister March" in solidarity with those marching in Washington and cities around the world in protest of newly-elected US President Donald Trump.
A group of concerned Durban women marched to the US Consulate in solidarity with the Womens March on Washington.
There was a solidarity march against Donald Trump in Johannesburg, South Africa, where marchers held up banners reading Black lives matter and Love trumps hate.

A crowd of about 100 people opposed to an upcoming by-election disrupted Electoral Commission of South Africa (IEC) officials from registering voters and damaged an IEC bakkie in a rural Mpumalanga village

Residents of Delmore Gardens in Boksburg took to the streets to protest against the governments move to erect an informal settlement close to their established residential area. They blockaded the road with burning tyres, stones, tree branches and other objects, demanding that the municipality call a halt to the construction.
SJC members held a picket outside the SAPS provincial head office in Cape Town.
A community worker was joined by Uitsig High School pupils, as they hand over a memorandum in protest to the Western Cape Provincial Legislature to keep their school open.
Aprotestin Booysens, Gauteng took place and left one person injured. Makhubela said several roads in the area have been barricaded with burning tyres and stones.

Business ground to a halt in Butterworth as an ANC faction protested against Mnquma municipal manager Sindile Tantsi.At one stage police fired rubber bullets at them as they marched towards the municipality's offices.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
NOTES: Protesting ANC Youth League supporters pushed their way into an Absa bank branch in the Durban central business district.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
NOTES: A protest march, led by the South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) and Cosatu and its affiliates in the education sector, took place in Polokwane.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
NOTES: Close to 4 000 SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) members took to the streets in the Pretoria city centre to protest, demanding that they be employed permanently.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
NOTES: Thousands of Unisa workers and NEHAWU members braved the pouring rain outside the Sunnyside campus in Pretoria to protest against the 6% salary increase offered by the institution.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
NOTES: About 50 employees of a Volkswagen SA logistics service provider have declared a strike over staff benefits and alleged nepotism and protested in Uitenhage. The workers were aligned to NUMSA trade union.
A group of women have gathered outside the Wynberg Magistrate's Court to protest against the bail application of a Westlake man accused of stabbing his wife to death.
A group of ANC supporters gathered outside a court building in Port Elizabeth singing songs and holding up placards with the words "hands off our councillor".
Students trying to register at Unisa in central Durban protested after they were turned away by Unisa staff, who brought registration to a halt.
Protestsin Ivory Park took place regarding dangerous road conditions. Residents blockaded Republic Road and Angel Fish Drive to highlight the dangerous road conditions.
Protests continuedin Booysens in Gauteng . Several roads in the area have been barricaded with burning tyres and stones.
A handful of Black-First-Land-First protesters turned out at Absa branches across Johannesburg .
Black First Land First movement held demonstrations out the ABSA banks in Polokwane.
Black First Land First movement held demonstrations out the ABSA banks in Pretoria.

A protest for clean drinking water turned violent North West's Moeka village, leaving a young man dead and several homes in flames. A young protester was fatally shot through the head by unknown men as he barricaded the road.
Nearly 200 supporters joined members of Reclaim the City in Sea Point park to raise awareness about the ongoing struggle to secure affordable housing in the city

Armed with placards that made use of existing biblical scriptures that preach unconditional love, a group of men and women held a picket outside Grace Bible Church in Pimville, Soweto to ask the church to promote unconditional love instead of homophobia.

The police in Galeshewe have arrested seven protesters as enraged residents in Galeshewe by barricaded a road with burning tyres and refuse material. Residents are protesting about poor service delivery at their settlement.
There were violentclashesbetween the residents of the Khayelitsha tract of land and law enforcement officers. Residents burnt debris in the road and stoned a law enforcement vehicle.
Teachers picketed outside the homes of the two mothers in Manenberg, blaming them for the shutdown of a creche facility, which has been operating for 25 years.

Traffic came to a standstill in parts of Potsdam as residents barricaded the road in aprotestto get electricity installed in various parts of the area.The disgruntled residents also burnt tyres, barricading traffic.
A power box was set alight on the R102 during a protest against an electricity blackout in the Fairbreeze area, Tongaat, north of Durban.
Protesters in support of the Bromwell Street residents who are fighting an eviction order picketed outside the Cape High Court in Cape Town.

Police and the Citys anti-land invasion unit faced-off against about 200 residents in Khayelitsha, resulting in rubber bullets, tear gas and stun grenades being used to disperse the backyarders in a second day of violence.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: UFAWU: United Food and Allied Workers Union
NOTES: About 500 FAWU-aligned workers, former workers and company managers from the South African poultry sector marched on the EU headquarters in Pretoria, furious over cheap imports and mounting job losses.
Ten people were arrested after at least six shops were looted in Itsoseng near Lichtenburg following violent protest in Itsoseng.
A small number of KwaZulu-Natal ANC Youth League members have gathered outside an Absa bank in Ballito demanding that the bank pay back money.
Protest action started in Barbarton over unpaid salaries and the abandoned rescue of three bodies trapped underground at Lily Mine.

Angry residents blockade a road in anger over the demolition of shacks in illegally occupied a piece of land in Wells Estate.Police had to fire rubber bullets when residents took out their anger by throwing stones at passing motorists.

A small group of mineworkers and residents blocked off a main road in Barbarton and burnt tyres in protest over unpaid salaries and the abandoned rescue of three bodies trapped underground at Lily Mine.
Glebelands Hostel residents are living in fear and some whistle-blowers have threatened to stop co-operating with the police after the killing of a murder witness.
Members of the Upper Highway Air non-profit organisation lead a protest march in Hillcrest calling for the closure and rehabilitation of Evniroservs Shongweni landfill site.
A man identified as a suspect in a weekend shooting spree in Oliventhoutbosch in Centurion was killed in an apparent mob justice incident
Rosettenville residents took to the streets and forced their way into homes they believed to be used for drug dealing and prostitution, carrying out the furniture and setting it alight.
Police are monitoring Vuwani in Limpopo, after protesters forced a satellite municipal office to close and brought schooling to a halt.
Ten people have been arrested after Bela-Bela residents petrol-bombed the mayor's private car and torched a building in the area. 1 person was shot and killed during the protest action.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: WAMUA: Women from Mining Affected Communities United in Action
NOTES: About 50 supporters of Women from Mining Affected Communities United in Action (WAMUA) from across the country chanted at the busy intersection of Lower Long and Walter Sisulu roads outside the Cape Town Convention Centre.
Several protests at Walter Sisulu Campuses in East London forced. campuses to shut down: Chiselhurst Campus
A small group of Durban University of Technology (DUT) students embarked on a peaceful march to the vice chancellor's office .
Hundreds of protesters gathered outside the Johannesburg officeof pharmaceutical company Roche over cancer deaths.
Several protests at Walter Sisulu Campuses in East London forced campuses to shut down: Potsdam Campus

Motorists travelling between Berlin and Potsdam were delayed for hours after residents of Baghdad and Kanana near Walter Sisulu University's Potsdam campus blockaded the road with burning tyres inprotestagainst lack of service delivery.
Service providers to the city of Pretoria have protested outside the office of the Speaker of Council, vowing not to leave until payments they say are due to them have been made.
During a murder trial at the Rustenburg Magistrate's Court, people gathered and protested outside.

The Rhodes statue in the Companys Garden (Cape Town) was covered with posters during a protest by Sonke Gender Justice against the gold mines. At the same time, Residents of Marikana and their supporters outside the Western Cape High Court.

A small group of protesters under the leadership of the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance marched to the Durban City Hall to voice their concerns about Eskom's controversial proposed new nuclear procurement programme for the country.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Students (South Africa); ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
NOTES: Walter Sisulu University students at the Nelson Mandela Drive campus (Mthatha) were chased off campus after they set alight a building and blocked the fire brigade from entering the premises. Earlier that morning, the ANC Youth League on the campus blocked access to the university

ALLY_ACTOR_1: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; BLF: Black First, Land First
NOTES: A metered taxi operator hoisted a placard at a march against Uber in Pretoria. Members of the EFF and Black First Land First joined the march in solidarity with the metered taxi operators
A man who allegedly stabbed his ex-girlfriend repeatedly in full view of commuters at a KwaZulu-Natal taxi rank in Richard's Bay has died after witnesses attacked him.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
NOTES: ANC and EFF supporters held separate protests in the Cape Town CBD before the President gave the State of the National Address.

Economic Freedom Fighters members and security dressed in white shirts clashed during the State of the Nation Address in Parliament ahead of President Jacob Zuma's State of the Nation Address (SONA). Tear gas, or pepper spray, was also apparently used in the public gallery.
Several Despatch residents took to the streets blocking Old Uitenhage Road with burning tyres.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League
NOTES: A group of members of the ANC Women's League protested outside the Moretele Magistrate's Court during a murder trial.

ALLY_ACTOR_1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; BLF: Black First, Land First
NOTES: More than 300 members of the African National Congress Youth League and the Black First Land First (BLF) movement brought the streets of Johannesburg banking district to a standstill during a march to Absa's headquarters, following the release of the Public Protectors report.
At least 10 houses suspected to belong to drug lords and brothel owners were set alight during a protest in Rosettenville.
SPLA shot and killed a Sister of the Catholic Diocese of Yei while on medical duty. Despite reports of arrests and investigations, justice had not yet been done as of February 2017.
Authorities arrested and detained the Ceasefire and Transitional Security Arrangements Monitoring Mechanism (CTSAMM) team leader in Torit.
Clashes between government forces and armed groups in Torit in Eastern Equatoria on 9 July following outbreak of violence in Juba. No reported fatality.
SPLA forces reportedly executed seven unarmed civilians in Torit.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.
SPLA gang-raped six women in Mayendit county in Unity state.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.
Three humanitarian workers were killed in August in South Sudan in unclear circumstances.
Reports of civilians being killed, raped and abducted and of the forced recruitment of children in areas including Guit in Unity in August and September.

Fighting in Lafon town on 8 and 15 August between SPLA and armed groups. On 8 August, armed groups reportedly gained control of the town, while on 15 August, SPLA came to retake the area from them. During the violence, reports of mistreatment of civilians by armed groups, forced recruitment by armed groups as well as forced displacement, abductions, sexual violence and heavy looting of nutrition supplies, medicines, schools and houses. The entire population of the town was displaced and as of four months later, only half had returned.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Heavy clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO in the Ifuotu mountains area in Eastern Equatoria left 11 SPLA and at least one opposition soldier killed.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA launched ground attacks on SPLA-IO positions near Lainya early September, burning down houses and looting properties.
SPLA forces razed the village of Lobonok, leaving unknown amount of fatalities and level of destruction in one of the most severe violence by government troops.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Aerial bombardements by SPLA on SPLA-IO positions near Yei early September.
Four humanitarian workers were killed in September in South Sudan in unclear circumstances.
SPLA abducted approximately 25 women, including at least two children, in Juba in September.
Reports of civilians being killed, raped and abducted and of the forced recruitment of children in areas including Guit in Unity in August and September.

ACTOR1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
NOTES: Members of the pro-Taban Deng Gai faction of SPLA-IO forces abducted 26 youths to forcefully recruit them into their forces in Thokwathnwyotni, Guit County, in Unity in September. One of them escaped. At least three others were abducted for the same purposes in Guit the same month.

Clashes between cattle keepers allegedly supported by SPLA and youth in Sindiru and Morsak villages in Central Equatoria in September resulted in at least a dozen deaths, 5,000 civilians displaced, homes torched and livestock looted.

Clashes between cattle keepers allegedly supported by SPLA and youth in Sindiru and Morsak villages in Central Equatoria in September resulted in at least a dozen deaths, 5,000 civilians displaced, homes torched and livestock looted.
Report of looting and harassment by uniformed people, including cases of rape, in September and October in the Kajo-Keji region.
Five SPLA soldiers allegedly abducted, raped and killed three women going to a local market in Yei county.
SPLA soldiers in civilian clothes reportedly raped three women in Guit county in Unity.
Around 1,000 SPLA soldiers and members of an armed militia reportedly burned and destroyed crops and looted properties in Ding Ding, in Unity.

ACTOR1: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
ALLY_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-); Unidentified Communal Militia (South Sudan)
ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes bewteen Dinka Bor cattle keepers backed by SPLA and local Youths with SPLA-IO elements in Lobonok between September and October, causing destruction to civilian property and displacement.
Clashes between SPLA and unidentified armed groups between Pajok and Ayaci in Magwi county, Eastern Equatoria, left several people dead.
Report that SPLA looted properties and livestock, raped women and girls, occupied schools and arrested several men on 3 October in Pajok, Ayaci, Palwar and Lerwa in Magwi County, Eastern Equatoria.
Report that SPLA looted properties and livestock, raped women and girls, occupied schools and arrested several men on 3 October in Pajok, Ayaci, Palwar and Lerwa in Magwi County, Eastern Equatoria.

SPLA soldiers allegedly attacked six villages in Matangai payam over 13-14 October, indiscriminately firing at civilians, pillaging their property and burning down at least 40 houses. Unknown number of casualties.

SPLA soldiers allegedly attacked six villages in Matangai payam over 13-14 October, indiscriminately firing at civilians, pillaging their property and burning down at least 40 houses. Unknown number of casualties.
Report of looting and harassment by uniformed people, including cases of rape, in September and October in the Kajo-Keji region.
Clashes between Maban community and Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile in Maban in November left at least 12 killed from the host community.
Report of attacks on vehicles along the road to Makpandu refugee camp throughout December and early January 2017, rendering the camp unreachable.
Report of armed clashes between unknown groups in Terekaka town in December, forcing aid workers to be relocated.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: NSS arrested six Sudanese refugees working as traders in Maban over allegedly transporting goods without paying taxes. One trader attempted to escape and the security forces reacted, beating him to death. This is believed to have sparked wider clashes in the days that followed.

Sudanese refugees from Blue Nile allegedly killed a local militia leader and burnt down his home in Maban, reacting to the killing of a Sudanese refugee trader by government forces on 22 December. This sparked wider violence in the days that followed between the local and refugee communities.
A fisherman was reported killed and another survived after an attack carried out by suspected Murle tribesmen at Ajwara area in Pochalla
gunmen raid a village near Torit and are pushed back by locals.
Local witnesses in Yambio accuse government forces of attacking and killing at least 5 civilians over the New Year period.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week

At least two people have been killed and six others are wounded after a public bus carrying passengers came under attack some 20 minutes drive from Torit town. Gunmen fire indiscriminately at the bus before retreating into the bush.
Unknown gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying people at Khor Langa area along the Juba-Yei road , resulting in 7 deaths.
Clashes between armed actors in Jikmir, Khoat and Kuetrengke payams in Luakpiny resulted in the burning down of property and forced displacement of thousands of populations.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Report of clashes between government and opposition soldiers in Nasser on 2 January, displacing populations from nearby villages. No mention of fatalities.
At least 15 people were confirmed killed over a land dispute at Kaljak area which lies on the border between South Sudans Northern Liech and Ruweng States.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese People's Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and the SPLA-IO in Hamra just outside of Kodok. The NDM claim to have more than 25 SPLA-IO soldiers during clashes on the first day.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Clashes between government troops and opposition fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

NOTES: Clashes between government troops and opposition fighters in five villages north of Yambio (Bazumburu, Bazungua, Bodo, Gitikiri and Rimenze). Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

Unspecified number of civilians killed in the fighting (10 spread over 4 locations), as well as houses burned down and property destroyed. At least 7,000 people were displaced from the area.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Armed clashes between government and opposition forces escalated in Eastern Equatoria on 3 January. No mention of fatalities.
five people were killed in separate incidents of cattle raiding in Northern Liech State at the beginning and the middle of the week
Unidentified men have kidnapped a Christian religious leader from his home in South Sudan's capital Juba

NOTES: Battles between Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement and the SPLA-IO  in Hamra just outside of Kodok. T. The SPLA claim to have killed 37 NDM soldiers. A senior NDM general Gatwech Chan is among those dead.
Seven people were confirmed killed and others wounded in an attack by gunmen along the Juba-Yei road near Jebel Kenyi in Loka.
government forces intercepted armed men when they attacked government positions in Torit. No casualties reported.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO accuse government forces of attacking their base in Nasser town with tanks and helicopters. No people reportedly killed.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Government claims that SPLA-IO forces loyal to vice president Taban Deng Gai captured a number of places in Upper Nile's new Latjoor state (Nordeng, Dhuoreding, Torpuot, Ketbek, Nyariew and Mandeng) from SPLM-IO forces led by Machar over 5-7 January. SPLA-IO forces denied the capture, except for Nordeng. Both sides said more than 40 of their opponents died during Jan. 5 fighting.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; Radio Easter
NOTES: One person was killed and six others injured when a soldier opened fire on a funeral rite in Yei. On the same day, another two people were killed in the Kimbi area of Yei by an unknown gunman.

NOTES: Agwelek forces under the command of Lt. Gen. Johnson Olony and allied to SPLA-IO pursued and killed a commander Major General Yohanis Okiech Okic of Lam Akol's NDM rebel group, along with his 27 bodyguards.

New party called the National Movement for Change (NMC) is formed from outside by the former governor of Western Equatoria. No mention if military campaign will be carried out or if will enter into agreement with active rebel groups of the country.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: 250 government soldiers defected to the armed oppposition led by Riek Machar in Mayom county, Unity State, accusing the government of tribalism and nepotism.
Unknown gunmen killed two people near Lokiliri county in Jubek state, as they were travelling from Magwi in Imatong State, to Juba.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Reported fighting between government and opposition near Yei town left 41 killed. Each side claimed victory and put the same number of fatalities on the other side.
Four people killed by suspected youth cattle raiders in Amolbut village, Lakes state, as they stole 60 heads of cattle and 30 goats from the area.

Suspected Murle tribesmen abducted a child at Tedo village in Pochalla North county. Around the same time, suspected Murle tribesmen also killed a member of Presbyterian Church near Kudbuudi village in Pochalla North county.
Murle tribesmen reportedly killed a local administrator in Neum village in Pochalla North county.
Unidentified gunmen abducted two children and wounded another in Bor East County.

SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; National Courier; Eye Radio
NOTES: Clashes between herders and suspected Murle tribesmen after an attack on Paluoch cattle camp in Duk Padiet by the tribesmen. At least 8 locals and 3 tribesmen were killed, while another 13 were injured and 2,000 cattle were stolen.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
SOURCE: Voice of America (Washington, DC); Sudan Tribune

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: Report that around 800 fighters from Lam Akol's National Democratic Movement defected to SPLA-IO led by Machar in Upper Nile early January. Lam Akol denied the report.
Clashes between local residents and suspected Murle tribesmen left at least two people killed and another wounded in Pentin village in Pochalla South County.
Government claims to have expulsed all remaining Sudanese SPLM-N rebels from Wau and Raja in Bahr el Ghazal out of the country in line with a 2012 cooperation deal between the two countries.
Residents living in displaced camps under UN protection in Juba demonstrated peacefully in support of Donald Trumps swearing-in as the 45th president of the United States.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
NOTES: SPLA-IO reportedly repulsed a government attack on their positions in Khor Natabu area along the Bringi-Wau road in Wau State. No mention of fatalities. Authorities denied the clash.
Clashes between local farmers and pastoralists south of Wau town left at least two dead.

Suspected herders from Tonj state killed three civilians in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County between 20-21 January, after their cows were allegedly raided by rebels. Houses were burnt down and large populations displaced from the area.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio; UN OCHA
NOTES: Clashes between government and opposition forces at Mondikolok Payam in Kajo-keji county. During the clashes, six civilians were reportedly killed, including a catechist, and one woman was raped, forcing thousands of people to flee to Uganda for safety. The clashes occurred after the SPLA arrested several persons in the area accused of supporting SPLA-IO rebels.

NOTES: SPLA-IO forces reportedly ambushed SPLA soldiers and supporting militias who were attacking and burning villages in Magwi county at Obbo Payam. At least 6 SPLA soldiers were killed. SPLA denied the claims.

NOTES: A clash between cattle keepers and SPLA-IO left at least six people killed in Wau state between 16-27 January, including two local community inhabitants, and many houses burnt down.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
SOURCE: South Sudan News Agency (SSNA); Sudan Tribune; Radio Easter
NOTES: SPLA reportedly attacked SPLA-IO positions in and around Yei but were repulsed by SPLA-IO, leaving 18 killed. Civilians were reportedly killed in the fighting and displaced to border areas. In the course of the fighting, SPLA soldiers allegedly burnt down houses in Lutaya area, including a Pastoral Centre of the Catholic Diocese.

ACTOR2: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
NOTES: A senior general loyal to former First Vice President Machar defected to the SPLA-IO faction allied to incumbent First Vice President Taban Deng Gai with 175 of his soldiers in Panyijiar County in Unity state. The day after, 11 military officers from the opposition Federal Democratic Party/ South Sudan Armed Forces (FDP/SSAF) also defected to the SPLM-IO under Taban Deng Gai, while beginning of February, one of the SPLA-IO officials in Canada also announced his defection to Daban Deng's faction.

Unknown assaillants killed a member of the opposition faction on the Ceasefire and Transitional Security Arrangements Monitoring Mechanism (CTSAMM) after he left the UN camp in Hai Jazeera near Wau town. Four men working inside the UN camp were later arrested over allegedly coordinating the killing.

SOURCE: Sudan Tribune; South Sudan News Agency (SSNA)

Alleged clashes between government forces and unknown gunmen in the week of 23 January after the gunmen ambushed a vehicle in Amaki along the Maridi-Rumbek road. No reported fatality. Authorities denied the claims.
Clashes between herders and local farmers as a farmer sought to prevent the herders' cattle to enter his lands in Pochalla North county in Jonglei left two herders killed.

NOTES: A number of new and unnamed armed groups have reportedly emerged in Upper Nile after having recently broken away from SPLA-IO led by Riek Machar. Ceasefire monitors underlined that it hampered their capacity to reach some parts of the country.

NOTES: Clashes between SPLA and SPLA-IO forces in Owachi area in Upper Nile, near Malakal. One shell landed close to the MSF clinic in Malakal town.

Academic lecturers indefinitely suspended lessons at the University of Juba to protest the arrest and detention of two academics the day before for holding an alleged secret meeting after being suspended from the university for demanding the Vice Chancelor's removal in December.

Ambush by armed youth from Abiriu county on cattle raiders from Rumbek at Amolbut payam in Abiriu, Western Lake state, left two of the raiders dead.

Suspected herders from Tonj state killed at least 11 civilians and burnt down houses in or around Wath-lelo, Atido and Maleng areas of Jur River County. Thousands of people were displaced to Wau town as a result of the tensions.
Shelling by South Sudanese air force on an IDP camp in Wau Shilluk area in Upper Nile left at least 5 civilians killed and 25 injured. Unconfirmed numbers of dead bodies in the bush.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on Sudanese refugees at Adjuong Thok camp in Pariang in Unity, killing at least one of them.
Shelling and mortar fire by South Sudanese forces hit an IDP camp in Wau Shilluk as well as the town's market, forcing populations to flee. No fatality.
Gunmen opened fire on a car along the Juba-Nimule road, leaving at least three people killed and several others wounded.

In Kuek, SPLA-IO claimed that SPLA was supported by Sudanese rebels from JEM and SPLM-N. Significant displacement reported from the area, with some humanitarian organisations shutting down operations due to insecurity.

Unknown gunmen attacked two humanitarian convoys between 29-31 January in Bentiu, Unity state, raising concerns about the safety of humanitarian convoys that take advantage of the dry season to preposition stocks in remote regions.

NOTES: Renewed clashes between government and opposition forces in Wau Shilluk, Upper Nile. The town was reportedly deserted.
